How do you think?

sb.servlet("/", new HomeServlet())
or
sb.servlet("", new HomeServlet())

What's the URL that a user connects to the servlet in those cases?
replies.author: minwoox
dominhhien

replies.bodyText:
What I meant was what's the difference between URLs when contextPath is "/" and ""?
Isn't it http://host:port/ in both cases?
replies.author: minwoox

replies.bodyText: Armeria server does not support empty service path (""). But servlet support empty path. If we access http://host:port, server return http://host:port/ => Http response status is 307 (redirect) instead of 200(ok) because URL was changed. If we support both cases "/" and "", Http response status always be 200 (ok).
replies.author: dominhhien

replies.bodyText:
Armeria server not support empty service path ("")

Right, Armeria does not support the empty path so a servlet on Armeria couldn't have empty path mapping. Isn't that right?
I was thinking just adding / after contextPath when we call
serverBuilder.serviceUnder(...); because the contextPath does not end with /
so that we can just handle the servlets by just adding one DefaultServletService.
When contextPath is /foo:

if a user adds a servlet too /bar, then the url is http://host:port/foo/bar

When contextPath is "":

if a user adds a servlet too /baz, then the url is http://host:port/baz
if a user adds a servlet too /, then the url is http://host:port/

When contextPath is /:

This is an exception.

timeline.bodyHTML:
We should make the list as immutable not just for getServlets(), but also for getServletNames(), getInitParameterNames(), getAttributeNames() etc.

return Collections.enumeration(servletRegistrationMap.values()
                                                     .stream()
                                                     .map(ServletRegistration::getServlet)
                                                     .collect(toImmutableList()));

Also, one thing we have to think about is that if the field is unmodifiable after DefaultServletContext is initialized, we can pass it when we create DefaultServletContext.
For example, initParamMap can't be changed after DefaultServiceContext is initialized.
So we can do something like:

class ServletBuilder {

    // Introduce a new class 
    private final DefaultServletContextBuilder servletContextBuilder;

    ServletBuilder(ServerBuilder serverBuiler, String contextPath) {
        servletContextBuilder = new DefaultServletContextBuilder(contextPath);
    }

    public ServletBuilder initParameter(String key, @Nullable String value) {
        requireNonNull(key, "key");
        servletContextBuilder.setInitParameter(key, value);
        return this;
    }

    public ServerBuilder build() {
        new DefaultServletService(servletContextBuilder.build());
        ...
    }
    ...
}

class ServletContext {

    ServletContext(String contextPath, Map<String, String> initParamMap ...) {
        this.initParamMap = ImmutableMap.copyOf(initParamMap);
        ...
    }
}

@Override
public void setSessionTimeout(int sessionTimeout) {

    this.sessionTimeout = sessionTimeout;
}

private void ensureUninitialized(String name) {
    checkState(!initialized, "Can't set %s after the servlet context is initialized.", name);
}

timeline.bodyHTML:
We have the logic for decoding cookies already. Let's use that:

final String cookieValue = httpRequest.headers().get(HttpHeaderNames.COOKIE);
if (cookieValue != null) {
    final Cookies cookies = com.linecorp.armeria.common.Cookie.fromCookieHeader(cookieValue);
    this.cookies = cookies.stream().map(c -> {
        final Cookie cookie = new Cookie(c.name(), c.value());
        cookie.setDomain(c.domain());
        cookie.setMaxAge(Ints.saturatedCast(c.maxAge()));
        cookie.setHttpOnly(c.isHttpOnly());
        ... // more settings
        return new Cookie(c.name(), c.value());
    }).toArray(Cookie[]::new);
} else {
    this.cookies = COOKIES;
}
timeline.author: minwoox

timeline.body:
Let's remove `decodeUrlParameter` and `decodeBody`.
We can use `QueryParam` for this purpose.
First we need to move this [logic](https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/linecorp/armeria/internal/server/annotation/AnnotatedValueResolver.java#L1203) to an internal public class to use together.
```java
package com.linecorp.armeria.internal.server;

public final class QueryParamUtil {
    ...
}
```
Then, we can use the method to parse assign to the field `QueryParams queryParams`.
So we can remove `parameterMap` and `unmodifiableParameterMap`.

So we can remove parameterMap and unmodifiableParameterMap.

replies.bodyText:
I think, we cannot use AnnotatedValueResolver.queryParamOf() because I want to QueryParamUtil will support at future:

parse parameters from url
parse parameters from body
parse upload files from multipart

AnnotatedValueResolver.queryParamOf() doesn't support all these features.
replies.author: dominhhien

replies.bodyText:
Thanks for the explanation. 😄
I think AnnotatedValueResolver.queryParamsOf() can

parse parameters from URL.
parse parameters from body.

But it cannot

parse upload files from multipart

It's because we do not provide multipart support on Armeria at the moment. However, once we support it, annotated services and Servlet will use the same logic to parse that. Which means that we have to put the logic in the same place.
So what I recommended is, could you just copy the code into the DefaultServletHttpRequest and use it? I will send a follow up PR that removes the duplicate code. 😄
replies.author: minwoox

timeline.bodyHTML:
How about using ByteBufs and storing them in an array?
So that we can write when close() is called?

private final List<ByteBuf> byteBufs = new ArrayList<>();

...

@Override
public void close() throws IOException {
    if (!byteBufs.isEmpty()) {
        response.getResponseWriter().write(
                HttpData.wrap(Unpooled.wrappedBuffer(byteBufs.toArray(new ByteBuf[0]))));
        byteBufs.clear();
    }
}

@Override
public void write(int b) throws IOException {
    byteBufs.add(Unpooled.copyInt(b));
}

@Override
public void write(byte[] b, int off, int len) throws IOException {
    byteBufs.add(Unpooled.copiedBuffer(b, off, len));
}

@Override
public void write(byte[] b) throws IOException {
    byteBufs.add(Unpooled.copiedBuffer(b));
}

Also, I think we can just ignore flush() call because we do not support streaming response in servlet.

timeline.body:
The `allToken` is always `*` so we do not want to specify it.
The class `StringUtil` is a bit complex because it's for ANT mapping. How about just using `Pattern` for simplicity?
We can just consider three cases:
- The path that ends with `*`. (e.g `/foo/bar/*`)
- Implicit mapping. (e.g `*.bop`)
- Exact path matching.

We might revisit this to optimize later though.
